eerhardt commented on pull request #6030: ARROW-7387: [C#] Support ListType Serialization
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r362666706
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Arrays/ListArray.cs
 ##########
 @@ -32,14 +32,14 @@ public class ListArray : Array
             : this(new ArrayData(dataType, length, nullCount, offset,
                 new[] {nullBitmapBuffer, valueOffsetsBuffer}, new[] {values.Data}))
         {
-            Values = values;
 
 Review comment:
   I think the existing behavior is better here - if I construct a `ListArray` instance with a specific `IArrowArray values`, I would expect the new `ListArray.Values` to return the same instance.
   
   There isn't a reason to create a new ArrowArray (which happens in the below constructor's `ArrowArrayFactory.BuildArray` call) when this constructor is already given the `IArrowArray`.
   
   Maybe we can split out a private helper "Initialize" method that both can call instead of having one constructor call the other?
   
   See [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/design-guidelines/constructor](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/design-guidelines/constructor)
   
   ✓ DO use constructor parameters as shortcuts for setting main properties.
   
   There should be no difference in semantics between using the empty constructor followed by some property sets and using a constructor with multiple arguments.
   
   ✓ DO use the same name for constructor parameters and a property if the constructor parameters are used to simply set the property.
   
   The only difference between such parameters and the properties should be casing.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r362667137
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Types/NestedType.cs
 ##########
 @@ -0,0 +1,47 @@
+﻿// Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more
+// contributor license agreements. See the NOTICE file distributed with
+// this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership.
+// The ASF licenses this file to You under the Apache License, Version 2.0
+// (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with

+// distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
+// WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
+// See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
+// limitations under the License.
+
+using System;
+using System.Collections.Generic;
+
+namespace Apache.Arrow.Types
+{
+    public abstract class NestedType : ArrowType
+    {
+        public IList<Field> Children { get; }
+
+        public Field Child(int i) => Children[i];
 
 Review comment:
   Why have this method when callers can just use the `Children` field to index into the collection? I don't think it provides much value over the `IList<Field> Children` property.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

 @@ -98,7 +98,10 @@ public void Visit(BinaryType type)
 
             public void Visit(ListType type)
             {
-                throw new NotImplementedException();
+                Flatbuf.List.StartList(Builder);
 
 Review comment:

 @@ -158,20 +162,21 @@ internal static ByteBuffer CreateByteBuffer(ReadOnlyMemory<byte> buffer)
             }
 
             var arrowBuff = new[] { nullArrowBuffer, valueArrowBuffer };
+            var offspring = GetOffspring(recordBatchManipulator, field, bodyData);
 
 Review comment:
   Why use the term "offspring" when everywhere else, including the spec, calls it "children"? #Closed

eerhardt commented on pull request #6030: ARROW-7387: [C#] Support ListType Serialization
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r359642601
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Ipc/ArrowReaderImplementation.cs
 ##########
 @@ -158,20 +162,21 @@ internal static ByteBuffer CreateByteBuffer(ReadOnlyMemory<byte> buffer)
             }
 
             var arrowBuff = new[] { nullArrowBuffer, valueArrowBuffer };
+            var offspring = GetOffspring(recordBatchManipulator, field, bodyData);
 
-            return new ArrayData(field.DataType, fieldLength, fieldNullCount, 0, arrowBuff);
+            return new ArrayData(field.DataType, fieldLength, fieldNullCount, 0, arrowBuff, offspring.ToArray());
 
 Review comment:
   It would probably be better if `GetOffspring` would return an array instead of an IEnumerable. That way can allocate the correct size array up-front to save on unnecessary allocations.  #Closed
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

eerhardt commented on pull request #6030: ARROW-7387: [C#] Support ListType Serialization
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r362675225
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Types/NestedType.cs
 ##########
 @@ -0,0 +1,47 @@
+﻿// Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more
+// contributor license agreements. See the NOTICE file distributed with
+// this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership.
+// The ASF licenses this file to You under the Apache License, Version 2.0
+// (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with
+// the License.  You may obtain a copy of the License at
+//
+//     http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
+//
+// Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
+// distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
+// WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
+// See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
+// limitations under the License.
+
+using System;
+using System.Collections.Generic;
+
+namespace Apache.Arrow.Types
+{
+    public abstract class NestedType : ArrowType
+    {
+        public IList<Field> Children { get; }
+
+        public Field Child(int i) => Children[i];
+
+        public int ChildrenCount => Children?.Count ?? 0;
 
 Review comment:
   `Children` can never be `null`, since the constructors prevent creating a `NestedType` with `null`. So maybe it would be better to drop this property all together and just let callers use `NestType.Children.Count` instead?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

eerhardt commented on pull request #6030: ARROW-7387: [C#] Support ListType Serialization
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r362688222
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Ipc/ArrowReaderImplementation.cs
 ##########
 @@ -209,4 +243,30 @@ private ArrowBuffer BuildArrowBuffer(ByteBuffer bodyData, Flatbuf.Buffer buffer)
             return new ArrowBuffer(data);
         }
     }
+
+    internal class RecordBatchEnumerator
 
 Review comment:
   (minor perf question) - how do you feel about defining this as a `struct` and passing it `by ref` to each method? That would cut down on this allocation and copying the `Flatbuf.RecordBatch` struct to the heap.
   
   It may not make major perf differences, but it would be less allocations.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

eerhardt commented on pull request #6030: ARROW-7387: [C#] Support ListType Serialization
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r362689518
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Ipc/ArrowStreamWriter.cs
 ##########
 @@ -332,6 +367,30 @@ private protected Offset<Flatbuf.Schema> SerializeSchema(Schema schema)
                 Builder, endianness, fieldsVectorOffset);
         }
 
+        private protected Offset<Flatbuf.Field>[] GetChildrenFieldOffsets(Field field)
+        {
+            if (!(field.DataType is NestedType type))
+            {
+                return new Offset<Flatbuf.Field>[0];
 
 Review comment:
   Should use `Array.Empty<Offset<Flatbuf.Field>>()` here instead. That will save on allocating a new empty array each time.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

HashidaTKS commented on pull request #6030: ARROW-7387: [C#] Support ListType Serialization
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r362799755
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Types/NestedType.cs
 ##########
 @@ -0,0 +1,47 @@
+﻿// Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more
+// contributor license agreements. See the NOTICE file distributed with
+// this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership.
+// The ASF licenses this file to You under the Apache License, Version 2.0
+// (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with
+// the License.  You may obtain a copy of the License at
+//
+//     http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
+//
+// Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
+// distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
+// WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
+// See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
+// limitations under the License.
+
+using System;
+using System.Collections.Generic;
+
+namespace Apache.Arrow.Types
+{
+    public abstract class NestedType : ArrowType
+    {
+        public IList<Field> Children { get; }
+
+        public Field Child(int i) => Children[i];
 
 Review comment:
   I added this method in order to prevent rewriting of a child. ( Like the [C++ implementation](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/arrow/type.h#L229))
   
   On second thought,  it doesn't make much sense. I think it is better to change the type of the Children property to IReadOnlyList<Field> and remove the Child method.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

users@infra.apache.org

+using System.Collections.Generic;
+
+namespace Apache.Arrow.Types
+{
+    public abstract class NestedType : ArrowType
+    {
+        public IList<Field> Children { get; }
+
+        public Field Child(int i) => Children[i];
 
 Review comment:
   I added this method in order to prevent rewriting of a child. ( Like the [C++ implementation](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/arrow/type.h#L229))
   
   On second thought,  this method doesn't make much sense. I think it is better to change the type of the Children property to IReadOnlyList<Field> and remove the Child method.

HashidaTKS commented on pull request #6030: ARROW-7387: [C#] Support ListType Serialization
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r362909980
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Ipc/ArrowTypeFlatbufferBuilder.cs
 ##########
 @@ -98,7 +98,10 @@ public void Visit(BinaryType type)
 
             public void Visit(ListType type)
             {
-                throw new NotImplementedException();
+                Flatbuf.List.StartList(Builder);
 
 Review comment:
   I suppose we don't need to do anything because of reasons below.
   
   * The `ArrowStreamWriter.GetChildrenFieldOffsets` method visits all children.
   * [`List` in `Schema.fbs`](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/format/Schema.fbs#L47) has no members.
     * When deserializing `ListType` from `FlatBuffers`, the `ValueField` data is created from children of `Field`.
     * I referenced the [C++ imprementation](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/arrow/ipc/metadata_internal.cc#L317)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

HashidaTKS commented on pull request #6030: ARROW-7387: [C#] Support ListType Serialization
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r362939845
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Arrays/ListArray.cs
 ##########
 @@ -32,14 +32,14 @@ public class ListArray : Array
             : this(new ArrayData(dataType, length, nullCount, offset,
                 new[] {nullBitmapBuffer, valueOffsetsBuffer}, new[] {values.Data}))
         {
-            Values = values;
 
 Review comment:
   Okey.
   
   Instead of creating an initialize method, How about changing the `ListArray(ArrayData data)` constructor as follows?
   
   ```
   public ListArray(ArrayData data , IArrowArray values = null)
               : base(data)
           {
               data.EnsureBufferCount(2);
               data.EnsureDataType(ArrowTypeId.List);
   
               Values = values ?? ArrowArrayFactory.BuildArray(data.Children[0]);
           }
   ```
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

HashidaTKS commented on pull request #6030: ARROW-7387: [C#] Support ListType Serialization
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6030#discussion_r362939845
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Arrays/ListArray.cs
 ##########
 @@ -32,14 +32,14 @@ public class ListArray : Array
             : this(new ArrayData(dataType, length, nullCount, offset,
                 new[] {nullBitmapBuffer, valueOffsetsBuffer}, new[] {values.Data}))
         {
-            Values = values;
 
 Review comment:
   Okey.
   
   Instead of creating an initialize method, How about changing the `ListArray(ArrayData data)` constructor as follows?
   
   ```
   public ListArray(ArrayData data , IArrowArray values = null)
               : base(data)
           {
               data.EnsureBufferCount(2);
               data.EnsureDataType(ArrowTypeId.List);
   
               Values = values ?? ArrowArrayFactory.BuildArray(data.Children[0]);
           }
   ```
   
   If users are confused by the `values` ​argument, how about adding this constructor as a new private constructor (without using a default value) and making both existing constructors call it.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

             : this(new ArrayData(dataType, length, nullCount, offset,

-            Values = values;
 
 Review comment:
   Okay.
   
   Instead of creating an initialize method, How about changing the `ListArray(ArrayData data)` constructor as follows?
   
   ```
   public ListArray(ArrayData data , IArrowArray values = null)
               : base(data)
           {
               data.EnsureBufferCount(2);
               data.EnsureDataType(ArrowTypeId.List);
   
               Values = values ?? ArrowArrayFactory.BuildArray(data.Children[0]);
           }
   ```
   
   If users are confused by the `values` ​argument, how about adding this constructor as a new private constructor (without using a default value) and making both existing constructors call it.

   > If users are confused by the values ​argument, how about adding this constructor as a new private constructor (without using a default value) and making both existing constructors call it.
